element.name: Evan's Tower by Windsockers, Traditional Cache (1/1.5)

long-description.p: In the grounds of St Ita's Hospital, stands a one hundred foot round tower. It was built by Sophie Evans in memory of her husband, George Evans M.P. who died in 1844. The door to to the Tower stands 15 feet from the ground (See Photo by Fr Aquinas T. Duffy). Originally there was also a marble bust of George Evans inside the Tower with the inscription "To the memory of George Evans M.P., an honest man, firm friend and true patriot. This monument a rivival of the ancient architecture of his country, is respectfully, affectionately and mournfully dedicated". This bust was later taken by Professor Pritchard Evans of Oxford University.

Sophie Evans (nee Parnell) was the grand auunt of Charles Stewart Parnell M.P. She also contributed to the building of the two catholic schools in the parish. To this day, each year a small amount of money (£20) is given towards the cleaning of the schools from the Sophie Evans Trust fund. She died in Paris but her remains were brought back to Portrane and she is buried alongside her husband at St Catherine's Cemetery Portrane.

The cache is a small container covered in black cloth
Please replace it with care to prevent muggles from finding it.
There is no access to the cache from the Portrane/Donabate costal path

ul.li:
2010-06-06T19:00:00Z : Found it by cmbdii
yay, bring gloves as there are a lot of nettles and brambles.

2010-06-06T07:00:00Z : Found it by molipix
Found after a nice walk in the rain. First cache for baby Georgie

2010-03-07T20:00:00Z : Found it by steokelly
Nice brisk day for a walk. Lovely location for cache great views. Found cache with wife and younger son. Found northern lobster geocoin will move to next cache we visit. Almost forgot we left pumkin pin....
[This entry was edited by steokelly on Sunday, March 07, 2010 at 3:44:56 AM.]

2010-01-31T20:00:00Z : Write note by orangetigerprawn
I forgot to log the geocoin drop when writing up the log.

2010-01-31T20:00:00Z : Found it by orangetigerprawn
Found while out and about with Mary Love. The teack to the cache was a bit muddy but still way above than average for the day. I dropped off my geocoin alter-ego. Farewell blood brother.
Go raibh maith agat as an taisce.

2008-09-27T19:00:00Z : Found it by Kersti.com
A lovely tower and a great view from here. Shame about the surrounding buildings which as jme1979 noted were quite run down. We entered via another path and soon found the likely location. Of course that's where it'll be but after searching no, it's not there - no way! Another search soon had the cache in hand. On exiting we finally saw the private property sign so we moved quickly!

wpt.name: GCZTPD
wpt.desc: Evan's Tower by Windsockers, Traditional Cache (1/1.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Evan's Tower
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Evan's Tower

In the grounds of St Ita's Hospital, stands a one hundred foot round tower. It was built by Sophie Evans in memory of her husband, George Evans M.P. who died in 1844. The door to to the Tower stands 15 feet from the ground (See Photo by Fr Aquinas T. Duffy). Originally there was also a marble bust of George Evans inside the Tower with the inscription "To the memory of George Evans M.P., an honest man, firm friend and true patriot. This monument a rivival of the ancient architecture of his country, is respectfully, affectionately and mournfully dedicated". This bust was later taken by Professor Pritchard Evans of Oxford University.

Sophie Evans (nee Parnell) was the grand auunt of Charles Stewart Parnell M.P. She also contributed to the building of the two catholic schools in the parish. To this day, each year a small amount of money (£20) is given towards the cleaning of the schools from the Sophie Evans Trust fund. She died in Paris but her remains were brought back to Portrane and she is buried alongside her husband at St Catherine's Cemetery Portrane.

The Cache

The cache is a small container covered in black cloth
Please replace it with care to prevent muggles from finding it.

There is no access to the cache from the Portrane/Donabate costal path


The Windsockers

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: yay, bring gloves as there are a lot of nettles and brambles.
Found after a nice walk in the rain. First cache for baby Georgie

Nice brisk day for a walk. Lovely location for cache great views. Found cache with wife and younger son. Found northern lobster geocoin will move to next cache we visit. Almost forgot we left pumkin pin....

I forgot to log the geocoin drop when writing up the log.

Found while out and about with Mary Love. The teack to the cache was a bit muddy but still way above than average for the day. I dropped off my geocoin alter-ego. Farewell blood brother.
Go raibh maith agat as an taisce.

A lovely tower and a great view from here. Shame about the surrounding buildings which as jme1979 noted were quite run down. We entered via another path and soon found the likely location. Of course that's where it'll be but after searching no, it's not there - no way! Another search soon had the cache in hand. On exiting we finally saw the private property sign so we moved quickly!
